Hi,

I don't know of an overview of data sets but just on those examples
you gave - sunspot activity averaged over a long enough period is
cyclical so is clearly predictable (see the chart in
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_variation).

Traffic congestion also follows regular patterns of course but can
also be highly chaotic and as such fits into the catagory of
Fractional Brownian Motion (FBM). FBM is a generalisation over normal
brownian motion, but both are random and as such inherently
unpredictable.

As an example of how FBM can be misleading consider predicting traffic
based on a daily cycle. The prediction works well for a while and then
some random event sends your error score soaring, e.g. long term
roadworks requiring a detour, natural disaster, traffic signal
failures perhaps caused by power outages (power consumption patterns
are similar in nature to traffic levels). Of course strictly speaking
sun spots also exhibit FBM - if you wait long enough the activity goes
off the scale and ultimately reaches zero, and the regular patterns
may change periodically also.

The best 'primer' on the subject I have encountered is the book "The
Misbehavior of Markets: A Fractal View of Financial Turbulence", by
Benoit Mandelbrot and Richard Hudson. Unlike Mandelbrot's other works
it's a very easy read and extremely light on the formal maths but
explains FBM very well nontheless.

I think a major point here is framing the problem correctly. E.g. we
/can/ predict traffic and many other things under /normal/
circumstances but we have to acknowledge the critical importance of
rare events; mitigating the effects of those may be better than
refining daily/weekly/yearly predictions. If I'm a company operating a
toll road then I should put some significant thought into what big
things could go wrong rather than trying to refine daily/weekly/yearly
predictions to better optimize my use of debt.

Apologies for drifting off-topic somewhat :)

Colin
